Claim: The US Should Recognize Palestine as a State.
The US has an obligation to recognise Palestine as a state.
Public opinion in the US supports this step: more Americans support an independent Palestinian state than oppose it.
Two thirds of all Americans - and even almost half of all Republican voters - believe America should either support or at least not block a UN resolution that recognizes Palestine as a state.
The US historical pattern of vetoing nearly every UN Security Council resolution unfavorable to Israel demonstrates that even an abstention would be a de facto endorsement of the resolution.
History makes it abundantly clear that citizens make social change possible by spurring the government to take action.
Informed citizens are able to improve policy-making; politicians enact policies that reflect public pressure and actually improve lives and society at large.
In 2019, citizens across 185 countries came together to raise their voices and call for governmental action against climate change.
In Ireland, abortion rights were secured largely as a result of campaigns championed by women.
In the United States, changes in public opinion toward the LGBTQ community preceded legislation that protected marriage equality.
Governments have taken admirable steps toward positive social change even when public opinion was unfavorable.

To help resolve the Mexican peso crisis, President Clinton loaned their neighbor country 20 billion USD. Although this move was met with sharp criticism and disapproval, the outcomes were positive for both the parties involved.
The racial desegregation of schools was undertaken by the government despite brisk opposition from the public.
According to Howard Zinn, "a radical historian," by implementing changes that facilitate social progress, such as racial desegregation, governments can create positive changes in public attitudes.
Desegregation amid unfavorable public opinion posed safety threats to Black children.

Resistance and backlash from dissenters can cause governments to backtrack their decisions. Such a move can be detrimental to the concerned parties, which is what happened with the recriminalization of homosexuality in India.

In democracies, governments and representatives are elected based on the majority vote. Therefore, it is unlikely that elected governments will make decisions that are diametrically opposed to those of the public.
The government, especially the judicial branch, should be neutral and objective, rather than giving in to public opinion.
In 2020, all major SCOTUS decisions were in line with public opinion, indicating that it is in some way adherent to social expectations.

Even if the desired changes are unequivocally desirable, ethical, and justified, the public may lack the depth and breadth of knowledge that the government possesses to foresee and mitigate the unanticipated adverse consequences that could result from hastily implementing the required changes.
The government possessing knowledge does not always mean that they will act on it; sometimes public pressure is necessary for change to occur.

The US is one of the world's most influential actors. If it were to officially recognize Palestine, it could serve as a powerful source of inspiration for other allies and nations to push harder for an independent Palestinian state.

By being the first major Western country to recognize Palestine, Sweden led the way for a number of others, including France, the United Kingdom, and Spain to do the same. US recognition could have an even more significant impact, given its international reputation.
American influence in Palestine is expanding; in 2021, President Biden moved to restore relations with Palestinians by reestablishing economic development and humanitarian aid programs.
The Biden administration made it clear that it supports a "mutually agreed two-state solution."
The United States is too late to serve as an international role-model, given that 70.5% of nations already recognize Palestine.
The ignorance of the American people could cause them to support unethical policies that could do more harm than good.
Studies from the 1990s indicate that Americans are less informed about foreign policy issues and world affairs than citizens of major European countries and Canada.
Many Americans lack basic geographic knowledge about the world and especially the Middle East.
Americans are bad at geography in general, not just when it comes to the Middle East, because their school curricula do not give this subject much importance.

In a 2016 survey of American college students, seven out of ten were unable to properly identify Israel, despite the fact that it was highlighted on a map along with three other Middle Eastern countries.

These numbers are persistent and represent not only students. As of 2006, three out of four Americans couldn't locate Israel or Iran on a map of the region. Two thirds couldn't find major theaters of US engagement like Iraq or major allies like Saudi Arabia.
The map used in the survey had actually redrawn the border, removing the West Bank; the missing chunk should have been a strong clue as to which country was Israel.
Only half of the students were able to pinpoint countries of major relevance for US foreign policy like Iraq and Iran.
Most Americans cannot properly identify US states on a map. This does not mean that they should not have or share their opinions on current affairs happening in their own country.
Poor geographic knowledge does not necessarily translate into a lack of knowledge about the pertinent issues required to form informed opinions.

The Israel-Palestine conflict is a battle over geographic territory. Thus, it is unlikely that the average American with limited geographic knowledge about the Middle East can form an informed opinion over the territory dispute.
Americans are particularly uninformed about the international aid provided by the US government.
Only one in twenty Americans knows that the United States spends about 1% of its GDP on foreign aid; the average estimate is 26%.
Only a third of Americans have ever heard of USAid, their country's own organization for international development. Even among college graduates this number only increases to 54%.
Nearly all Americans believe foreign policy is important enough to be taught in high school or college.
Greater knowledge about foreign policy issues is unlikely to change public opinion, which is often rooted in sentiments rather than facts.

While this is currently the case, public support for Israel has been increasing, while support for a Palestinian state is decreasing; given that the current margin in favor of a Palestinian state is small, it is likely to disappear in the future.
Policies are not based upon expected future voter preferences, but current voter preferences. Given that, the US should recognise Palestine as a state since a majority of the population supports it.

Two thirds of Americans sympathize more with Israel than with Palestine; only 15% think the other way around. This makes the recognition of Palestine against Israel's explicit preference hard to sell.

The vast majority of Republican voters sympathize more with Israel than with Palestine and do not consider a peaceful two-state solution viable. Politicians in Republican-dominated US politics have little to gain from defying this.

Almost half of all Americans - and a majority of Republican voters - believe that the Jewish people are God's chosen people. This makes policies perceived as going against Israeli interests hard to sell (p. 9).
In the same vein, only a very small minority of 6% would like to see the Trump government lean towards the Palestinian side in this conflict.
This is only because the majority of voters want the Trump administration to lean towards neither side, so this does not indicate a general attitude of support for Israel.

The public attitude towards Israel gives American politicians little incentive to support positions that run counter to Israeli interests. In fact, support for Israel has been labeled as "cheap talk," giving politicians large benefits with minimal risk (p. 20).

Sympathising with Israel is not mutually exclusive to establishing a Palestinian state. The American public can blame Hamas for its aggressive actions but still believe that the Palestinian people deserve a state.
Surveys indicate that the American public would be in support of less amicable and supportive relations with Israel.
More than half of Americans believe that their government should abandon the principle of not openly criticizing Israel and its policies, as some demand.
Almost half of all Americans support the unprecedented step of imposing sanctions on Israel in reaction to new settlements in Palestine (p. 21).
Six out of ten Americans believe that the United States gives too much or even far too much foreign aid to Israel.
However, less amicable and supportive relations are not the same thing as unilaterally recognising Palestine at the expense of American-Israeli relations.
Even if citizens desire an action to be taken, it may not be ethical for a government to deliver it.
This is particularly true when the desired action entails interference in the affairs of other countries.
Ironic, considering the United States is the country that most interferes with the internal affairs of other sovereign nations.
Some governments are not motivated by ethical decision making; they are more concerned with optics and protecting their domestic priorities.
Given that recognizing Palestine as a state will benefit the US, they have an obligation to act in the best interests of their citizens.
Recognition of Palestine could improve the image of the US in the Arab world.
As recognition of Palestine would be perceived as a step in opposition to Israel's stated interests, this is likely to be perceived positively throughout the Middle East.

Few people in major Middle Eastern countries have positive opinions on Israel; they do not see the country as a contributor to peace and stability in the region, or view relations with Israel as important (pp. 5, 7, 8).
The Palestinian conflict colors public perception of the US in the Arab world.
The citizens of major US allies including Saudi Arabia and Egypt, see the occupation of Palestinian territories as a highly problematic issue.
Egyptians in particular believe that "normalization with Palestine’s enemy is a betrayal of the Palestinian cause, which is central in Egyptians’ interests.”
Recognizing Palestine could garner support for the US in these countries.

Given that the majority of the Arab world, including Saudi Arabia and Egypt, aren't democracies, the beliefs of private citizens are largely irrelevant compared to government priorities in regional security and economic interests.

Israel opened its first diplomatic mission in the United Arab Emirates (UAE) three months after it stopped bombing Gaza in 2015. The Gulf states have signed covert deals with the Israeli defence contractors to gain access to the IDF’s prized military technology. This is used to secure oil wells. Economic interests trump the demand for a Palestinian state.

The fact that these countries have backdoor relations with Israel indicates that these relations are important for their regional security and economic interests. Being able to establish a more open relationship is in their interests; these countries will therefore care about whether public opinion permits an open relationship.

Pressuring Israel for a peace deal will likely alienate it as Israel does not want to recognise an independent Palestine. This risks destroying whatever gains have been made through backdoor and covert diplomacy.
Even dictatorships are receptive to popular will to some extent. Complete disregard for popular opinion always leads to instability.

While it might be that popular perception is not as important for state actors to the extent that they are non-democratic, it still influences many other aspects of national relations, since a nation is far more than simply its state.
A study found that people in Jordan, Lebanon, and Iraq ascribe little importance to the Palestinian issue.
Given the US's history of intense opposition to recognising Palestinian statehood, a decision this unprecedented and of this magnitude would have a massive impact on Arab perceptions of the US.
In the Arab world, the Palestinian issue is predominantly responsible for the prevailing attitudes towards America.
All Arab countries recognise Palestine as a state.
The roots of anti-Americanism in the Arab world are far deeper than just the recognition of Palestine.
US policies are largely responsible for anti-Americanism.
Anti-Americanism is unlikely to immediately disappear from the Arab world, following formal recognition of Palestine.
Though recognition of Palestine is a key issue and would improve the standing of the United States in the eyes of the Arab world.
The recognition of Palestine is not as crucial of a factor as some believe with regards to the public perception of the United States.
Perception of the United States has improved slightly in the Arab world; yet the official US government stance on Palestine has remained the same.
US recognition would be unlikely to actually alleviate the plight of the Palestinian people, so anger at the US for perpetuating the conflict up to the present day would persist.
Recognizing Palestine would improve America's standing among the people of Palestine.

Internal and external accords, laws, and policies require the US to intervene and improve the lives of Palestinians. Negative perceptions of the US among Palestinians can make this delivery of assistance and support more challenging.

Palestine has many natural resources, which are currently being exploited by Israelis. Improving perceptions of the US among Palestinians could facilitate the establishment of businesses that benefit the local people (e.g., job creation) as well as the US economy.

The Palestinians know their side of the conflict is legitimate. Unless the US de-recognises Israel at the same time as recognising Palestine, it won't gain any particular credit from the Palestinians for recognising what is perceived by Palestinians as reality.
America should not recognise Palestine, as even if their standing improves, it is less important than other outcomes.
Palestine has barely 4.5 million citizens and an economy the size of Burkina Faso's. It is hardly relevant for the United States as a partner or market.
A favourable image of the US allows for a better relationship between the US and Arab countries to form, which could lead to better trade agreements and intelligence sharing.

The US conducts operations in several countries in the Middle East, which they could do more easily if Arab countries had a more positive image of the US. Willingness to help and cooperate would likely be higher if the attitude towards the US were more positive.

In their operations in Iraq, the US military relied heavily on assistance from local translators. The willingness of translators to cooperate, and of the local population to tolerate people who cooperate with the US military, was dependent on public perception of the US.
If there are pragmatic benefits to be gained through cooperation, Middle Eastern states will cooperate with the US regardless of "perception" of the US' morality as an actor.
Any improvement of America's reputation in the region will be limited as the Israel-Palestine question is only one of many issues that determine how America is seen.
The US has a track record of military interventions in the Middle East which have negatively shaped perceptions.
The violence and death caused as a result of these military interventions leads to resentment towards the US.
News coverage of massacres or collateral murder, such as the Baghdad airstrikes in 2007, antagonizes bystanders and supports radical thinking against the US.

American interference in the region is generally not seen by public opinion as one of the most severe obstacles to peace and stability in the region - not even in countries directly affected by it like Iraq (p. 11).
The presence of US soldiers alienates the local population.
The habits of US soldiers radicalize some locals as they drink alcohol and behave outside social norms, as was observed in Saudi Arabia.
US military bases and soldiers are a magnet for terrorist attacks, risking the lives of those nearby. In the 1990s, the base in Saudi Arabia was moved because of this.
A military presence is interpreted by some as an all out war against Islam. For individuals that link their identity to Islam, this can be seen as an attack on themselves.
Negative stereotypes about Westerners as 'selfish', 'violent' or 'greedy' help to perpetuate Anti-Americanism.
The US supports corrupt autocracies in the region and thus fuels anti-Americanism (p. 9).

In non-democratic countries supported by and allied with the US, such as Iraq, the United Arab Emirates and Jordan, the lack of representative government is seen as the primary obstacle to peace and stability in the region (p. 11).

Surveys show that American culture and political values are generally seen as positive, whereas American policies in the Middle East evoke opposition - with the policies towards Palestine being among the prime sources (p. 15).
Any benefit to US-Arab relations would be negligible at best and at worst it would be seen as a betrayal of one of their key regional allies, Israel.
Israel's enemies around the world (including Hamas and the PA) will not be pacified by recognition, or even the creation of a Palestinian state - only by the destruction of the Jewish one.

Hamas and other vocal enemies of Israel could hardly sell more amicable relations to their domestic audiences and supporters after decades of hateful rhetoric towards Israel and threats of destruction.
US allies in the Middle East are more concerned about their own socio-economic conditions and security than about Israel.
America shouldn't be concerned about the reaction in Israel.
Israel does not behave as an ally to the United States.
Israel has a history of spying on the US, the most notable example being espionage by the ex-intelligence analyst Jonathan Pollard.
Israel's diplomatic efforts against the most important multilateral deal led by Obama were not consistent with an alliance.
The Israeli Prime Minister went to the US congress to undermine the President of the United States.
While one might expect one of America's closest allies to play a supportive role in times of conflict, Israel has been a strategic burden in the past.

During the Gulf War in 1990-1991, the US government had to intentionally prevent Israel from joining the coalition against Iraq because its participation might have led to more Arab support for Iraq or possibly even have caused some Arab countries to leave the coalition altogether.
This singular instance from a quarter of a century ago is hardly representative of the United States' relationship with Israel as a whole.
Some nations in the Arab League have diplomatic ties with both the US and Israel.
Egypt's relations with Israel are the best they have been in history.
Israel and Egypt cooperate on regional security concerns such as Hamas and terrorist groups in the Sinai peninsula.
Since al-Sisi came to power in 2013, security cooperation between Egypt and Israel has reached unprecedented levels.
Increased ISIS attacks in the Sinai peninsula have forced Israel and Egypt to cooperate more closely.
While that may have been true in the past, more recently Egypt has actually sought to improve relations with Hamas in order to secure the Sinai peninsula.
Hamas officials are regularly invited to Egypt and the two keep communication channels open.
Egypt's calls for peace between Israel and Palestine is widely considered one of the most likely solutions to resolve the conflict.
Egypt is putting pressure on both sides to broker a long-term peace deal.
Egypt was largely responsible for brokering peace in the "Sword of Jerusalem" vs. "Guardian of the Walls" conflict in 2021.
Egypt is Israel's closest regional partner.
Egyptian officials held a number of meetings with Israeli businessmen in 2021, showing their relationship is growing even stronger.

Historically, Egypt permitted flights to Tel Aviv under a one-plane airline called Air Sinai, which did not bear the Egyptian flag. In March 2021, they announced that EgyptAir would absorb Air Sinai and that Tel Aviv-Cairo flights would be tripled.
Despite the close government relationship with Israel, the Egyptian people are wholly against normalizing ties with Israel.
In 2020, four Arab League nations, the United Arab Emirates, Sudan, Bahrain, and Morocco, signed agreements to normalize ties with Israel.

The 2020 agreements between Arab nations and Israel were less about the latter, or peace in the region, and more regarding the benefits, and political and militaristic favors offered by the United States.

There exists a 'moderate axis' of Middle Eastern nations, including Egypt, Turkey, Saudi Arabia and several of the Gulf states, as well as Jordan, that have offered Israel a wide margin of flexibility to pursue the war on Hamas. Public calls for peace are accompanied by backdoor diplomacy.

These nations perceive Hamas to be an Islamist threat that could destabilise their own countries. Iran's support and funding of Hamas has effectively made these nations prioritise the destruction of the group over the recognition of a Palestinian state.
The Gulf states fear Hamas' link with the Muslim Brotherhood, which they believe is backed by Iran.

The negative perception of Israel's defiance of international law, occupation of Palestinian territories and military engagements with surrounding countries, reflects poorly on the US as the "principal enabler" of this behavior.

Surveys from countries like Britain show Israel's unpopularity. Among non-European countries, British people feel more unfavorable only towards North Korea; even Iran is perceived as more favorably than Israel (pp. 10-11).
Recognizing Palestine, and thus taking a more moderate stance on the conflict, would serve to dissociate the US from Israel's actions.
About as many Germans hold a negative opinion about Israel as a positive one. The most common attributes associated with Israel by the majority of Germans are ruthlessness and aggressiveness (p. 31).
Recognition of Palestine would undermine the belief that the US only respects international rules and UN institutions when it can take advantage of them.
In light of other actions taken by the US, recognising Palestine will not convince anyone that the US respects international law when it does not benefit itself.
The US has prevented an investigation of alleged war crimes by the US Army in Afghanistan.
Former US President Donald Trump declared that Israel and other allies should be immune to the ICC, and threatened the ICC with sanctions should they go ahead with investigations.

That the US has not recognized the legitimacy of other national or international courts does not mean that it should not. Indeed, the treaties and conventions that have established International Law are in principle binding on the US.
National interests often override potential public relations damage, otherwise the US would not have supported regimes that are far worse and more unpopular than Israel.

Given the long history of the US providing unwavering support for Israel, one largely symbolic move by a single administration wouldn't substantially affect the international perception of the country.
Negative perceptions of Israel do not exist in a vacuum, so they should be taken with a grain of salt.
Some believe that, as the international media tends to assign blame for the region's conflict primarily to Israel, it has become "an amplifier for the propaganda" of radical Palestinian forces.
Some evidence demonstrates that American television stations and newspapers are biased in their reporting on the Israel-Palestine conflict by casting Israel as the sole aggressor (pp. 113-114).
Reporting by Al-Arabiya and Al-Jazeera often casts Palestinians as victims and Israelis as aggressors. Palestinian perspectives and suffering are emphasized over the Israeli experience (p. 16).

Previous research that decries media coverage of Israel and Palestine was conducted by a group connected with American Israel Public Affairs Committee (AIPAC) - the country's largest pro-Israel lobbying group. Its publications should be seen as agenda-driven.

Negative views of Israel don't stem solely from their defiance of international law, but also from widespread anti-Semitism. Due to the link between anti-Semitism and negative perceptions of Israel, the U.S should not be guided by the latter.

Given their history of allyship and common interests, the US will continue to maintain close ties with Israel regardless of whether it recognizes Palestine. Therefore, recognizing Palestine as a state is unlikely to change any reputational damage that the US suffers from its association with Israel.
Negative attitudes towards Israel often function as "communicational detours" to bypass norms against expressing anti-Semitic views.

US recognition of Palestine will be perceived not just as a dissociation from Israel's actions towards their neighbour, but also as a general repudiation of Israel as an actor. Even if negative perceptions of Israel are based on anti-Semitism, the US's image will improve.
An analysis of 33,000 New York Times articles featuring Israel found that the newspaper often cast Israel in a favorable light.
Palestinian voices are actively silenced across a variety of social media sites and communication platforms.
Zoom cancelled an academic webinar to be held by a Palestinian activist.
The Palestinian activist in question is a known terrorist and could have been planning to propagate certain ideas or behaviors that run contrary to Zoom's terms and conditions.
Research has shown that YouTube, Google, and Facebook have all systematically blocked Palestinian content on their sites.
Given that unwavering support for Israel is primarily the result of strong, organized lobbying on US politicians, such a decision would show the ability of US decision makers to remain independent.
In terms of funding provided to members of Congress, the Pro-Israel lobby ranks among the top 30, far above any other country-specific lobby group in the US.
Funding provided by the Pro-Israel lobby was steadily increasing from 2002-2018; but, in 2020 it exploded, more than doubling contributions from 2018.

US Congressmembers are given campaign contributions based on their stance towards Israel. However, the vast majority of Americans are unhappy with the extent to which Congress defaults to supporting Israel because of money.

This indicates unhappiness towards politicians supporting Israel by default, not against supporting Israel for rational reasons. The former is a corruption of democracy, while the latter is a politician doing their job.

The Pro-Israel lobby ranks among the top five most influential lobby groups in American politics, alongside national organizations such as the NRA and the American Association of Retired Persons (AARP).
The pro-Palestinian lobby is poorly organized, making the pro-Israel lobby seem stronger than it is in reality.
Cursory Google searches about the pro-Palestinian lobby provide very little information and are dominated by the pro-Israel lobby; websites are down, and Wikipedia articles are unfinished.
Google's own employees have formally requested the search engine to be more forthcoming in recognizing the Palestinian struggle.
The two are not mutually exclusive; the pro-Israel lobby can be considered strong regardless of the relative power, or lack thereof, of the pro-Palestine lobby.

If the United States were to distance itself from Israel, this could be interpreted as abandoning a close ally. In turn, it could have severe repercussions for other close allies causing the interlinked system of alliances to suffer.
President Obama doubled down on an "unshakeable commitment to Israel's security." Recognizing Palestine could be interpreted as a weakening of this commitment to American allies.
The US can recognise Palestine without compromising its commitment to Israel's security - defence pledges and aid deals will still remain.
Trump's actions to undermine NATO cast doubt on US loyalty and commitment to longstanding alliances. Betraying Israel by recognising Palestine would reinforce and deepen this distrust.
Although the US and Israel share several close allies, it is possible for the US to denounce Israel for its actions while also reaffirming its relationships with other common allies.

The US has consistently reaffirmed its support for Israel. A move like this would indicate that public US affirmations of support are worth little, and do not necessarily indicate underlying US policy.

When the United States recognized China in the 1970s, this was perceived as a de-facto abandonment of Taiwan. Even though the US reaffirmed its commitment to other allies, several of them were shocked and opted for less reliance on America in their security affairs (p. 710).
Israel's withdrawal from occupied areas following US recognition of Palestine will create a political and military vacuum that could open the doors for militant groups to take control of the state.
Although ISIS is a relatively new presence in Palestine, 7% of Palestinians and 13% in the Gaza Strip perceive ISIS as representing true Islam. This could enable ISIS to gain a foothold in Palestine.
Naftali Bennett, the current PM of Israel, has argued that this a resurgence in violence is exactly what would happen should Israel withdraw. He cited historical precedent, as proof.
When Israeli forces withdrew in 2005, their withdrawal was quickly followed by a resurgence of violence.
The violence cited by Bennett could have been caused by the respective Israeli occupations causing a surge in support for radical parties, not subsequent withdrawal.
Hamas and Fatah, the two dominant groups in control of Gaza and the West Bank respectively, will never be able to work with each other. This could increase conflict in the region.

Hamas and Fatah have fundamentally different approaches to the state of Israel. Hamas believes the state does not have the right to exist, and Fatah believes it does, choosing to attempt political solutions instead.
While President Mahmoud Abbas has declared security cooperation with Israel as sacred, Hamas has vowed to end that cooperation.
Hamas and Fatah's multiple past attempts to work together have resulted in failure. Even when deals are brokered by Egypt, the groups struggle to put their differences aside.
Past behavior and prioritisation may be indicative of what Hamas and Fatah are likely to do; however, future co-operation cannot be ruled out entirely.
Hamas is often considered an extremist group, and would would never accept a power-sharing agreement.

Keeping hostilities going and even going to war periodically with Israel ensures the survival of Hamas. In order to go to war, Hamas needs to be in control of territory within Palestine, for which purpose it will hold on to Gaza.

Hamas fears that Palestinians will eventually tire of a military approach to the conflict. A war with Israel leads to countless deaths of innocent Palestinians; this fuels Palestinian hatred for Israel and paints Hamas as soldiers fighting for the Palestinians.

If Palestinians were to have a stable state of their own, going to war would become far less attractive. This suggests that Hamas would very likely either have to moderate itself, or cease to have popular support.
Hamas was founded with the explicit purpose of destroying the state of Israel - ruling Gaza gives Hamas the foothold in Palestine it needs to be able to launch attacks against Israel.
Hamas decided to contest the upcoming municipal elections in the West Bank, indicating a clear interest in ruling the area long term.
In 2015, 39% of Palestinians in Gaza said they would vote for Hamas, more than any other political group. This would make it a strong political actor in the region.
In 2021, 53% of Palestinians supported the group.
Many radical groups have accepted power-sharing agreements and joined the political systems of recognized governments.
Maoist rebels in Nepal now successfully share power in the country's government, through an agreement that ended a long-running civil war.

Though the party formed by the former Maoist rebels is now the most popular one in the country, some remnants of their foundation as rebels has permeated modern society, with leadership unwilling to make changes. This has caused strife among opposition parties and it will be difficult to form a coalition and strike a balance.
The post-Apartheid government of South Africa is led by the ANC (African National Congress), an organization the US had formerly labeled as a terrorist group.

Northern Ireland managed to form a government in 2007 between the Democratic Unionist Party and Sinn Fein - both of which have historic paramilitary links. This suggests that former terrorist organizations can be integrated into government more easily after peace has been established.

Sinn Féin and the DUP were deadlocked in negotiations over the formation of a power sharing government for approximately three years. This suggests that the ability of factions to find common ground does not necessarily last.

A similar solution was implemented in Lebanon, where the conflicting parties entered an inter-religious power sharing agreement. This has allowed the various religious and ethnic groups within Lebanon to live peacefully together.

Because of its sectarian divisions, Lebanon is a country that is notorious for its political instability. If anything, it is an example of the problems that states with long-standing ethnic and religious divisions suffer.
The Kosovo Liberation Army (KLA) was described as a terrorist group by US officials before eventually forming part of the government and armed forces of the (partially recognized) country.
71% of attempted power-sharing agreements in Asia between 1989 and 2006 failed due to a resumption of fighting.
These groups were largely not opposed to US foreign policy when they were legitimized by the US. Hamas, on the other hand, has threatened attacks against the US.
Hamas has not yet targeted US citizens, proving that their threats are little more than rhetoric (p. 194).

The designation of "terrorist organization" is an arbitrary distinction that does not necessarily reflect the manner of violence, the scale of violence, or the threat to the United States. The designation is based only on political concerns.
Hamas is a terrorist organisation in part because it is not a government. No democratically elected government is seen as a terrorist organisation and Hamas would be no different.
The US government has yet to declare the KKK a terrorist organization. Their rules for acknowledging terrorist groups seem to be arbitrary at best, and knowingly deceitful at worst.
Hamas, or at the very least their military wing, is responsible for suicide bombings as well as rocket and mortar attacks and kidnappings against the state of Israel. This is more than political.
Both Hamas and Fatah realise that they need to work together, and have agreed to form a new National Council in order to hold elections.
Hamas is taking measures to become a more moderate and open political group - this indicates that Hamas could work together with Fatah and the Palestinian Authority.
In the past, Hamas has violently clashed with Fatah to establish control over key areas. Clearly, the group has little intention to share power.
In 2007, Hamas expelled Fatah from Gaza after refusing to accept the election results. Since then, the two governments have been operating separately in Gaza and the West Bank, respectively.

The current conditions of the Palestinian territories are what provides radical groups a foothold. By providing Palestinians with the right to live in their own state, they will have little need to turn to radical Islamists.

The Palestinian economy has seen a trajectory of "strong growth" in the past despite massive challenges. This demonstrates an economic dynamism that would make it unlikely to collapse into a failed state.
GDP growth in Palestine is expected to return to 3.5% in 2021.

Growth tends to be cyclical and dynamic; a 2017 report from the IMF spoke of "increasingly difficult conditions" for the Palestinian economy and mentioned that the "outlook for the economy is daunting." This is hardly an optimistic evaluation of Palestine's prospects.

Economic growth alone is by no means a predictor of whether a state can descend into domestic turmoil. All major states of the Arab Spring - Tunisia, Egypt, Libya, Yemen, Syria and Bahrain - experienced steady and moderate economic growth of around 4% prior to the events of 2011.
The risk of conflict resulting from Israel's withdrawal from Palestine is anticipated; therefore, preemptive steps to mitigate adversity can be planned and taken prior to withdrawal.
Recognition may improve Palestinian perceptions of the US, but it will alienate Israel - a US ally.

US recognition of Palestine would require 800,000 Israelis to withdraw from the West Bank and cost Israel a vast some of money, given that the evacuation of 8,000 settlers from Gaza cost Israel $9 billion. This expense would have major ramifications for diplomacy between the two nations.

Elsewhere, the cost of resettlement of 100,000 settlers in Israel has been estimated to be around $10 billion. Since the total number of settlers is multiple times of that, resettling all of them would cost enormous amounts of money.
The problem could be mitigated by land swaps through which Israel keeps territory with major settlements.
About half of all Israelis support in principle the idea of land swaps to retain Israeli control over territory with major settlements.

Independent proposals based on the situation in 2011 estimate that swaps involving merely 5% of Palestinian territory and no dislocation of Palestinians could bring about 80% of settlers onto Israeli territory (p. 11).
Almost 80% of settlers live within the Israeli West Bank barrier, which could be used as a line to mark areas for land swaps.

The Israeli West Bank Barrier is illegal under international law, built on Palestinian territory, and an arbitrarily defined border. There is no reason why this barrier should be used as the border to decide land swaps.
It is unlikely that Palestinians would be willing to accept this barrier - which they oftentimes refer to as an "apartheid wall" - as a permanent border.

In order to reduce the amount of territory annexed by Israel, other options would exchange a mere 3.7% of Palestinian territory and still be able to bring almost 70% of settlers onto Israeli territory.
Land swaps will mean some Palestinians will either end up living in Israel, where they are likely to face discrimination, or they will be forced to relocate, which is unfair towards them.
Even if land swaps were fair and would put an end to all settlements, a solid majority (65.4%) of Palestinians oppose the idea.
A number of independent plans for land swaps have been proposed under which no Palestinian villages would be annexed and no Palestinians displaced.

There has been considerable expansion of settlements since 2011, and more constructions of settlements promised by the current government. This renders plans based on the situation in 2011 irrelevant.
The sheer number of settlements, as well as the distribution throughout almost the entirety of the West Bank, would make this an incredibly difficult task.
In Gaza, only about 8,500 Jewish settlers had to be relocated. In contrast, the number of settlers in West Bank who would need to be relocated is about 50 times greater.
In 2013, the Arab League endorsed the idea of mutually agreed-upon land swaps indicating that, though difficult, land swaps are possible.
Land swaps are simply a negotiating tactic used by Israelis to legitimise the ongoing expansion of settlements.
The only land swap map put forward by Israel so far prejudices Palestinian contiguity, water aquifers, and the viability of Palestine. Mutually agreeable land swaps are likely to be impossible.
Israeli Arabs have previously refused land swaps as they oppose being transferred under Palestinian authority.
Palestinian authorities and communities have rejected land swaps on numerous occasions in the past.

Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority has stated that land swaps must be based on land of equal size and value, yet Israel still hasn't committed to this principle. This alone dooms the possibility of agreeing on land swaps.
Hamas has declared its opposition to land swaps.

In the 2000 Camp David peace talks, both sides agreed to a solution: adjusting pre-1967 borders so that the largest settlements are under Israel's control in exchange for more land for Palestine elsewhere. Withdrawal from other, much smaller settlements was considered to, consequently, be easy.
Israel tends to respond harshly when the international community moves against it, which could cause problems for the US.
Israel previously reacted poorly when the UN condemned settlements; ambassadors were withdrawn from every country that voted in favour of the resolution.
Recognising a Palestine which does not accept Israel as a Jewish state could cause Israel to lash out and accuse the United States of tacit support for anti-Semitism.

Recognition of a Palestinian state prior to an agreement undermines existing negotiations between the Palestinians and Israelis. This will likely alienate Israel from any discussions of a two-state solution.

The Israeli government has emphasized in the past, and the Israeli public has stated in surveys, that the preferred method of engaging with the Palestinians is through bilateral talks. Thus, the involvement of and pressure from third actors will likely be received negatively.
Recognition does not constitute involvement in the talks. Thus, it is fully compatible with bilateral talks between Israel and Palestine.
The right wing establishment in Israel is thoroughly opposed to the creation of a Palestinian state. Unilateral action by the US will likely push it further away.
If the US recognises the Palestinian state, Israel could be provoked to act aggressively against Palestine, which could result in worsened conditions for Palestinians.

Recognition would constitute a big step towards increasing Palestine's chances to become an independent state. Israel does not want this to happen and would want to prevent this while it's still possible.

By many accounts, the current PM, Bennett has an even stronger anti-Palestine rhetoric than his predecessor. US recognition of Palestine would increase their threat to Israel, which would be followed by harsher sanctions against Palestine, thereby gaining Bennett more support from voters.

The rally-round-the-flag effect is a sudden increase in approval ratings following periods of international crisis or war. Though often applied to US presidents, a leader of Israel could gain support from more patriotic voters, should they attack Palestine.
Recognition of Palestine has prompted retaliation from Israel in the past.
Israel suspended a payment of $127 million due to the Palestinian authorities, as a response to Palestine's accession to the ICC a day after the statute was signed.

In response to the UN's recognition of Palestine, Israel confiscated £75 million that it was supposed to pay Palestine and announced that it would build 3000 new settlers' home in areas that the Palestinians had earmarked as part of a future state.
Palestine does not pose a military threat to Israel, so the need for aggressive action is minimal, if not non-existent.
Unlike Israel, Palestine has no air force, navy, tanks, nuclear, chemical, or biological weapons, ballistic missiles, or space technology.
While Palestine does not possess the military capacity to destroy Israel, the threat of terrorist attacks and mortar fire from groups such as Hamas still exists.

In one study, more than one-third of Israelis reported prior exposure to terrorism, and about half had a relative who had previously been exposed to terrorist attacks. Such experiences may account for self-reported fear of terrorism among Israeli participants, particularly when compared to Swedish participants.
In the cited study, the correlation between prior exposure to terrorist attacks and fear of terrorism was statistically non-significant.
Every year Israelis die from terror attacks committed by Palestinians or launched from Palestinian territory.

Though Palestine may not currently pose a military threat to Israel, they still consider Palestine to be an inherent threat to their own existence. Because Israel fears Palestine, they could feel it vital to strike against Palestine before they become strong enough to pose an actual military threat.
Israel has fought at least three wars in Palestine in the last decade and regularly conducts air and artillery strikes against Gaza. It is difficult to see how they could act more aggressively.

US recognition of Palestine might get Israel back to the negotiation table by signaling disapproval of current Israeli policies on the peace process. This can encourage the Israeli public to question its government's stance, as that is leading to increasing international isolation.
Israel is already largely isolated in international public opinion, but so far has not seen this as a reason to change its policies.
Israel has few other allies and is generally not seen favourably abroad. In the BBC's 2013 popularity ranking, it is on one of the last ranks, just ahead of North Korea.

If the United States were to recognize Palestine, it is unlikely that Israel would position itself against not only the majority of the international community but also its most important ally by becoming more aggressive towards Palestine.

If America were to recognize Palestine, it would defy its close ally's interests whilst also refusing to act against the interests of other countries it is less invested in economically and diplomatically. This would seem unfair.
Out of respect to India, the US does not recognize the independence of Kashmir even though it is far less invested in diplomatic ties with them than with Israel.
The USA publically supports the Chinese annexation of Tibet.
A deterioration in Israel-US relations will jeopardize America's operations and presence in the region.

Israel is strongly opposed to the Iran nuclear deal. If Israeli-US relations deteriorate as a result of US recognition of Palestine, Israel may launch a pre-emptive strike against Iran, raising the possibility of a regional war.

Israel was close to preemptively striking Iran in the past. A falling out with the United States might embolden Israel to do so next time - and thereby torpedoing America's politics in the region, for example the 2015 nuclear deal with Iran.

The threat of Iran acquiring a 'break-out' weapon after ten years, when the Iran Nuclear deal expires, may lead Israel to strike Iran, especially if it feels it is losing US support and must protect itself.

Amos Yadlin, the former head of IDF Intelligence, claimed that it was highly unlikely that a missile strike by Israel would lead to a regional war, primarily because Iran was aware of Israel's ability to destroy it in an all out war. This in turn would threaten the survival of the Iranian regime.
The Israeli military and intelligence community supports the Iran nuclear deal.

Official Israeli statements on Iran are nothing but political rhetoric. Multiple Israeli security officials, including Israeli Chief of the General Staff Lieutenant General Gadi Eizenkot, have stated that Iran's nuclear threat has been pushed back by at least 10-15 years, if not eliminated.

The Israeli security establishment has warned Netanyahu to not touch the Iran nuclear deal. They assessed that destroying the nuclear deal will unite the Iranian people behind the regime, and possibly even push it to pursue an all out nuclear option.

The Israeli political and security establishments are split on their attitude towards the Iran deal. Despite the security establishment's acceptance of the Iran nuclear deal, Netanyahu could still order an attack on Iran.
Israel could sell sensitive military technology that either the US shares with it or it creates itself in retaliation for US recognition (p. 12).

Israel is a world leader in the development of unmanned aerial systems, for both intelligence collection and combat, and it has shared with the U.S. military the technology, the doctrine, and its experience regarding these systems (p. 10). America's ability to gather intelligence could be restricted if Israel decided to cut of trade in military technology.

Washington insisted that Israel agree to stop selling problematic weapons and military technology to China and deprive itself of both a major market for its world-class military exports and a source of influence with Beijing. Without this pressure, Israel would resume selling weapons to China (p. 9).
Israel has a track record of selling US arms to third countries without authorization. This was the case when Israel transferred arms to Sub-Saharan Africa, China, and Taiwan.

If Israel already has an established track record of selling arms to third parties without authorisation, then it seems unlikely that the recognition of Palestine will meaningfully change the state of affairs.

Israel has not been above using blackmail against the US to get what it wants. In 1973, during the Yom Kippur War, its cabinet reportedly engaged in "nuclear blackmail", by demanding an emergency airlift of arms and supplies from the US, depicting self-defense with nuclear weapons as the likely alternative (pp. 225-240).
Although often-repeated, this narrative of "nuclear blackmail" has been called into question as it was never confirmed by named sources in public.
Due to Israel's reliance on American support for equipping its military, it is unlikely that Israel would endanger this support by going against its supplier's interests.
The US also provides vital defense technologies that Israel would not have access to otherwise.

All airplanes and nearly all helicopters of the Israeli Air Force were bought from the US. With an eye on its international position, it is unlikely that Israel would be able to procure military technology on this level from elsewhere.
Selling sensitive military technology would hurt Israel as much as the US, as Israel shares many of the same enemies. This would make intentional leaking of technology unlikely.
While relations between the US and China are growing worse over conflicting priorities of trade and security, Israel and China have vowed to deepen relations.
While US relations with Russia are at their lowest point since the Cold War, Israeli relations with Russia are the warmest they have ever been, despite conflicting goals in Syria.
Presumably, the US would stop sharing sensitive technology with Israel if the latter started selling it as a form of retaliation for the recognition of Palestine.

Israel did not retaliate against the other 138 countries that recognized Palestine as a state, hence it is unlikely that it would retaliate against its closest ally and greatest source of foreign aid.

A few of these countries, like Iran and Syria, are open enemies of Israel. Nonetheless, Israel did not retaliate against them when they recognized Palestine. It seems unlikely that Israel would then retaliate against its greatest ally and foreign aid source.

The US relies on Israel for crucial intelligence about Hamas, Hezbollah, and al-Qaeda and its affiliate groups in the region (p. 11). Deterioration of relations could put this intelligence cooperation at risk.
Intelligence about Hamas and Hezbollah is of relevance for the US only insofar as it helps to protect Israel. Neither organization targets America.
Al-Qaeda is no longer a relevant threat to the US.
Jihadist terrorist attacks against US targets (abroad and domestic) by ISIS and al-Qaeda have drastically declined since their peak in 2015.
By many accounts, the biggest security threat to the United States is white supremacy.
Even if al-Qaeda as an organization may have become irrelevant, the ideology, attitudes, and recruiting tactics that underlie it persist in other organizations, such as ISIS.
While ISIS is a bigger threat to US interests overseas, al-Qaeda is still a relevant threat to the US homeland.

Al-Qaeda's hatred of the US and their demonstrated willingness to commit terror attacks makes them inherently dangerous, regardless of its current state. As long as al-Qaeda exists, it could return to relevancy and threaten the US again.
Al-Qaeda has begun to build affiliate networks and branches in Arab Africa, carrying out attacks across the continent and demonstrating that they are still a very relevant threat to the world.
Since the 9/11 attack, the US has developed adequate capabilities to predict and ensure national security, regardless of the level of threat al-Qaeda poses.

Countries like Saudi Arabia, Egypt, Qatar, Kuwait or the UAE find it difficult to side with the US publicly on Iran unless "Washington pressures Israel on a peace initiative". If anything, recognition increases regional cooperation with the US.
The US already shares intelligence and sells weapons to Saudi Arabia, independent of the situation in Palestine. Regional cooperation and a Palestinian peace deal are not linked.
Saudi Arabia, Qatar and the UAE have a strong anti-Iran position due to sectarian tensions. The US does not need to pressure them for support.

The US is seeking to form an anti-Iran coalition with Arab states that would share intelligence with Israel as well. A peace deal is not required for Arab nations to cooperate with the US when their interests align.

Israel has no US military bases, whereas other regional players with poor historic relations with Israel do. A deterioration in the Israeli-US relationship would not affect US' capacity to project power regionally.
Israel might not have any US military bases but they certainly have US civilians joining their military. Alienating Israel could force those citizens to have to choose a side.
The United States would not lose much by alienating Israel.
Even if the US were to alienate Israel, they may spend less on aid, freeing up funds that the US could spend elsewhere.
The US has spent almost $100 billion on Foreign Military Financing (FMF) since 1985 (p. 22).
Israel is allowed to convert about a quarter of FMF military aid into shekels to spend at home (p. 2). Such expenditure therefore does not wholly benefit the US.
The FMF provision that allows Israel to spend 26% of military aid domestically is being phased out, requiring Israel to spend all military aid within the US by 2021.
FMF payments are meant to enable foreign governments to purchase American military products and services. The money therefore comes back home and supports the US economy.
Israel is not a top partner for the US.
Israel is not even among the top-20 of America's trade partners measured in trade volume.
37% of Americans believe that Israel has too much influence on their politics; a portion significant enough to influence geopolitical decision-making (p. 4).
Israel is not even among the top 20 in terms of the national origins of tourists visiting the United States. Countries of comparable size, like Sweden and Switzerland, outrank it.
In a Republican-dominated era of US politics, the opinions of Republican voters are most influential. The majority of them believe that Israel has the right amount of influence (p. 4).

Israel is a prolific exporters of arms. In the past, the US was able to influence the targets of these exports, for example by blocking sales to China. If this leverage was lost, the US could be vulnerable.
Close association with Israel is a burden so it may serve the US well to weaken ties.
The extent and unconditionality of American support for Israel has been described as going against America's strategic and moral interests.
The majority of Americans do not perceive Israel as a burden to the United States.

Even if the actual benefits are hard to quantify, three out of four Americans believe that Israel provides "essential military and intelligence cooperation" for the United States in the region (p. 38).
For decades, the US has been almost entirely dependent on Israel for intelligence regarding the Middle East.
Geo-strategic security policies are not made with public opinion in mind, given they often do not reflect reality.
The public is not always aware of the intricacies of international politics, and is thus unlikely to be aware of the cost to their country of such a close association with Israel.
Israel hosts a large-scale American war reserve stock with some $1.8 billion worth of equipment for use in case of armed conflict in the region.
Israel is far too dependent on the US to destroy relations.
Israel's trade is highly dependent on the United States: 37% of its exports go to America, 14% of its imports come from there. No other country plays an equivalent role for Israel's trade.
In fact, Israel exports more to the United States than to its eleven next largest trade partners combined.
Israel receives almost 1% of its GDP in foreign aid from the United States, more than any other country and about 9% of America's foreign assistance budget.
U.S. military aid for Israel has been designed to maintain Israel’s “qualitative military edge” (QME) over neighbouring militaries. This is vital to its regional security.
US aid accounts for 20% of Israel's defence budget and 40% of the IDF budget. Israel is therefore heavily dependent on the US to maintain its defences.

Israel's dependency is shrinking. Whereas the size of its economy has tripled over the last two decades, the size of aid payments has stayed the same. The share of US aid among Israel's GDP thus sunk from about 3% to 1%.

Israel can hardly be said to be militarily dependent on the US. Even excluding America's military aid, it spends one and a half times as much on its military than all of its neighbors combined; the share of its GDP that it spends on the military is the highest among all the world's major armies.
No other country sends as many tourists to Israel as the United States; American tourists make up one quarter of all tourism arrivals in Israel and contribute to one-third of tourism revenue.
In the past, American tourists have shunned countries they perceived to act in opposition to US interests.
A variety of religious and cultural sites in Israel are important to Christians, Jews, and Muslims; many Americans will have reasons to visit Israel regardless of U.S. official policies.
Twenty-eight UN member states do not recognize Israel and do not permit their citizens to enter the country, limiting the number of people that can actually visit Israel.
The US is one of the most populous countries in the world; the number of arriving tourists is bound to be high in any country visited by Americans.
The US supports Israel diplomatically, allowing it more freedom than unsupported states.
The United States has adopted a "don't ask, don't tell" attitude towards Israel's nuclear program - a privilege which no other officially non-nuclear state enjoys.

Without tacit American acquiescence, the international community might call into question Israel's nuclear program and attempt to pressure the country into signing the Nuclear Non Proliferation Treaty.

There has been international pressure on Israel to give up its nuclear weapons - without the support of the US, this international pressure may increase and force Israel to give up its nuclear weapons.
The outsized power that any nuclear power has in international relations would likely continue to insulate Israel from any pressures to end their nuclear weapons program.

Damaging its relationship with the US would isolate Israel in the international community. This isolation could set in motion a diplomatic avalanche that will ultimately weaken Israel’s position in negotiations with the Palestinians.
Israel's diplomatic position is quite strong following the Abraham Accords; these opened up trade with previously hostile neighbours and cemented Israel as a regional power player.

The US has repeatedly voted against all other members of the UN Security Council, vetoing resolutions that would have criticized Israel, including those on settlement expansions, assassinations, violating the Geneva Convention, attacking UN supplies, and killing UN workers.
American diplomatic support for Israel has never been unequivocal. The US has supported, abstained from and vetoed UN resolutions criticizing Israel in the past.

Until December 2016, out of 226 UN Security Council resolutions related to Israel since 1948, the US has abstained from less than two dozen of them. It has only voted against Israel a handful of times.
Even when the US was supposed to play a neutral role - for example during the negotiations of the Oslo Accords in 1993 and in Camp David in 2000 - it de-facto sided with Israel.
Israel's status as a nuclear power allows the country to be independent of the whims of major powers like the United States.

Nuclear weapon use is strictly regulated, if not prohibited, under most circumstances. At best, they are effective deterrents against states, not terrorist organizations like Hamas and Hezbollah, which are Israel's main threats.

It would be politically unviable for the US to completely cut off its aid to Israel, as most US voters are staunchly pro-Israel, or would oppose cutting off aid. Given this, Israel still has plenty of room to be intransigent and aggressive in reaction to the recognition of Israel.

American citizens' views of Israel have remained steadily positive since 2001, despite occasional Israel aggression against Palestine. While many might think some sanctions are acceptable, cutting off aid completely would likely be a step too far in the eyes of pro-Israel Americans.

Israel could be made to feel its dependence on the United States even without a complete cut-off of relations. In 2004, the American government threatened to exclude Israel from the F-35 jet program, reducing its capacity to update its jets.
46% of Americans support imposing sanctions on Israel in response to settlement-building.
Israel has a large conventional arms industry. As a result, Israel's security is not dependent on good relations with the US.

Dependence on US aid has institutionalized Israeli reliance on air power and ever-more-advanced technology, at the expense of focusing more intensively on ground maneuvers and the unique threat posed by enemies waging asymmetric warfare. Israel would be better off without this aid.

Israel's defense industry is actually undermined by US aid which forces it to "buy American". By restricting the amount that can be spent domestically, Israel's defence industry faces layoffs and closures.
Palestine is a legitimate state and deserves to be recognised as such.
The legal definition of a state is enshrined in international law via the Montevideo Convention of Statehood (p. 3); Palestine fulfills the criteria outlined in the convention.
Palestine has the "capacity to enter into relations with the other states" as it has a web of diplomatic representations around the world.
Palestine has a permanent population of around 4.7 million. Therefore, Palestine fulfills criterion 1(a) of the Montevideo Convention (p. 3).
Palestine clearly fulfills the territory criteria as it rests upon a strip on the West Bank and in Gaza.
Whilst there have been significant settler attempts to undermine Palestinian contiguity, some have recently been overruled.
It seems unlikely that recently attempts to claim land that settlers have been expelled from will be successful, as it was developed by Palestinians in recent history.
The Israeli government, under Naftali Bennett, is expected to use an old Ottoman law to claim the land.
If attempts to weaponise old Ottoman land law to legitimise settlements go unchallenged by Biden, then they are likely to become a mainstay of land claims from Bennett's government.
The territory of the proposed Palestinian state is disputed. More than half of the West Bank, Area C, has a majority Jewish population that would rather stay under Israel's sovereignty.
A significant portion of the Jewish population of Area C lives there due to illegal settlement.
Palestine does not have contiguous borders, but is instead made up of an archipelago of areas of control, broken up by Israeli settlements and highways.
Netanyahu proposed a plan to apply sovereignty on Jewish settlement in the West Bank, effectively annexing 30% of the West Bank and creating a multitude of Palestinian enclaves.
It is unclear why the nature of a state's borders bears on its legitimacy, particularly in a modern context in which physical travel is less important.

Other countries, too, have split territories and exclaves. French Guiana is part of France, Alaska and Hawaii are part of the United States and the Kaliningrad Oblast is part of Russia, even though none of them share a border with their country's main territory.
It is circular to deny Palestine the recognition of a state, which would presumably consolidate its territory, because its territory is not consolidated at the moment.
Palestine lacks a single sovereign government which can enforce laws throughout its dominion.
Palestine is politically divided between two factions: Hamas, which controls the Gaza Strip, and Fatah which controls the West Bank.

Even though Abbas's government does not have control over the entire territory, it is already the only sovereign recognized by most world governments, including the United Nations, whose representative is appointed by Abbas. In this respect, it is no different than any other state that does not fully control its territory.

Pakistan, Nigeria, India, Ukraine, and Phillippines are just a few of the many states in the world that have militant organisations carrying out violent atrocities within their borders, yet they are all recognised as states.
Palestine does not have a monopoly on violence over the area it claims.
Palestine currently has no unitary security force. Fatah controls the Palestinian Security Services, while Hamas has de-facto created its own security force in the Gaza Strip.
The cause of Palestine's failure to meet traditional concepts of statehood is Israeli occupation.
Israeli forces regularly conduct raids into Palestinian areas of the West Bank to arrest suspected terrorists.
Israeli intrusion should not render a state illegitimate: the US frequently intervenes militarily in countries without their consent, but that does not make their governments illegitimate.
The frequency of these raids would presumably diminish drastically if this recognition strengthened the ability of the Palestinian state to maintain control itself.
Official recognition of statehood by the US could facilitate processes to unify control of Palestine; the granting of statehood could be made contingent on this happening.
Fatah and Hamas have already indicated a willingness to form a unity government. US recognition could enable greater international cooperation in the formation of that government.
Israeli occupation is unlikely to change, should the USA recognise Palestine as a state.
Recognition of statehood from the US could increase the ability of Palestinian governments to exert power within their borders and establish a monopoly on violence.
Recognition by many other nations confirms a state's legitimacy as it normalises the social order of the state, and brings it into the sphere of international relations and law.
The people of Palestine have the right to self-determination - this is far easier to attain when their state is internationally recognised.
Palestinians previously inhabited an area greater than it currently does - much of their land has been stolen, actively restricting their right to self-determination.
Expulsions and the illegal occupation of land that had been temporarily vacated during the war of 1948, called the Palestinian Exodus, shaped the land claim of the early Israeli state.
The conquest of Palestinian territories by Israel in the Six-Day War was illegitimate.

As the land taken in the defensive war did not belong to any entity called "Palestine" framing the claim as a "conquest of Palestinian territories" is fallacious. The area in question had been held by Jordan.
Jews existed in British-mandated Palestine and could have been considered Israeli. A significant portion of modern day Israel was legally purchased off Arab inhabitants.
The land wasn't considered stolen when it was under Jordanian and Egyptian control.

In 1945, the land owned by Jewish peoples made up merely 7% of the combined area of Israel, the West Bank, and Gaza, with half owned by the JNF and PICA. It is hard to imagine how the remainder - nearly 19,000 square km - could have been legally purchased off Arab inhabitants.
While individual Palestinians may have claims to land because it was stolen from them, this doesn't establish the legitimacy of a Palestinian state that postdates this theft.

At the very least, by indicating that the Israeli claim to the land is based on theft and therefore not legitimate, it strengthens the Palestinian claim to the land and therefore to self-determination.
All Palestinians have suffered from the flow-on consequences of the initial theft of land; they therefore all have a moral claim to the land.
If modern Israel's legitimacy postdates its historical narrative, which is over 2,000 years old, then the 100-year-old Palestinian rights are also valid.
As Palestinians were forcibly expelled from Israel, their claim to sovereignty was never legitimately extinguished, so they still have a right to control over parts of the region.
Historical records disprove the theory that Palestinian Arabs fled the state voluntarily or at the behest of Arab leaders. Instead, they were forced to flee because their lives were endangered.

The current nonexistence of a Palestinian state is due to the rejection of a partition plan by Arab leaders in 1948 and subsequent acts of warfare against the new state of Israel by Arab nations. Given that Palestinians voluntarily forfeited their opportunity to receive a state, they are not entitled to one now.
Palestine has no history as a unified state; it existed as part of other states before the 20th century.
Arab leaders in 1919 denied that there is a distinct country called Palestine, instead associating it with Syria.

Given that there are no historical roots for the state of Palestine, the US should not recognize them; instead, the US should recognize the Palestinians as a distinct people living within the state of Israel.
Whilst Palestine was not a state historically, it is considered one today as those living within it request statehood, and unified recognition.

The U.N. partition recommendation called for more than half of then Palestinian land to be allocated for a “Jewish State”. This was unreasonable as the Arabs were a majority in Palestine at the time, and owned more land than Jews in every single district in the region. The 1948 plan was unfair and deserved to be rejected.
Even if the agreement was unfair, the violent reaction against Israel from surrounding Arab nations was unjustified.
Violent reactions can be justifiable; the German occupation of Poland was unfair, and the subsequent violent reaction against Germany was justifiable.
Palestinians never had a claim to sovereignty over the area in the first place; Britain did, as Palestine prior to 1948 was part of the British Mandate.

The British Mandate was a legally binding instrument created by the League of Nations and backed by the San Remo declaration and the treaty of Sevres (1920) whereby the previous sovereign divested itself of any claim to the area. The mandate recognised the rights of Jews to reconstitute their national home.

The British Mandate for Palestine was a piece of legislation produced by a colonial organisation, the League of Nations, with little regard for the rights of Palestinian Arabs. It should not be considered a legitimate cession of Palestinian moral ownership of the area.
The right to self-determination is not a tangible element of international law and has no clear content or obligations; it is rather a vague moral principle recognized by various bodies (p. 3).
Even where there is agreement on the existence of a people, it is not clear what the right to self-determination entails and how precisely it can be exercised (p. 5).
It is not clear how to define "peoples" and whether the Palestinians therefore have the right to self-determination.
In numerous cases the applicability of the right to self-determination is disputed, for example in the case of the Kurdish people and the Basque people.
If the right of the Palestinian people to self-determination clashes with the same right of the Jewish people, it is not clear how both can be respected.

Palestinians have a right to a nationality; however, this does not imply a UN right to a state of their own. Their rights to security and a stable life could be equally satisfied by giving them citizenship in another country, either Israel or Jordan.

Jordan has no interest in accepting Palestinians as its own citizens, in part because it fears being transformed into a Palestinian state. It currently refuses entry and citizenship to, or forcibly deports, Palestinian refugees.
Palestinians living in Jordan but originally from the Gaza Strip, which was under Egyptian authority until 1967, have no right to Jordanian citizenship.
The easiest path to citizenship is only open to Palestinians that lived in Jordan between December 1949 and February 1954.

Following the loss of the West Bank to Israel, Jordan became actively hostile against Palestinians in the northwest of the country; terminating in a conflict which suppressed Palestinians, expelled militants, and permanently scarred relations between the two nations.
Jordan has recently been arbitrarily withdrawing citizenship from people of Palestinian origin.
Millions of Palestinians already have, or are eligible to apply for, Jordanian citizenship.
Many other states have recognised, or indicated their willingness to recognise, an independent Palestinian state - this indicates that it has an appropriate status as a nation.

135 members of the UN recognise Palestine as a state. Palestine was therefore recognised by a higher percentage of nations at the time of its failed application to the U.N. in 2011 (68 percent) than Israel was (64 percent) when it was successfully admitted in 1949.
Palestine has more states recognising it than any other partially-recognised state not recognised by the US.
The European Union has consistently declared its support and readiness for recognising a Palestinian state. This is outlined in both the 1980 Venice Declaration and Berlin Declaration of March 1999.

The EU has invested heavily in the two-state solution; since 2007, EU member states have provided almost 2.5 billion euros worth of support to Palestinian state building efforts, not including annual contributions of more than 200 million euros for the UNRWA, the UN Relief Work Agency that carries out projects in the occupied territories.
Several other polities are partially recognised, however the US has not historically seen this as a compelling reason to recognise them itself.
84 UN states recognise the Sahrawi Arab Democratic Republic (Western Sahara), however the US does not.
The Republic of China (Taiwan) is recognised by 19 UN member states, as well as the Vatican, but not by the US.
It may be possible to reduce the number of international law violations if the US recognises Palestine; this move creates political pressure.

The UN Fact Finding Mission in Gaza found that "some of the actions of the Government of Israel might justify a competent court finding that crimes against humanity have been committed," for example the naval blockade. If Palestine were to be established as a sovereign state, these crimes would receive more attention and condemnation from the international community.
The only way for the Palestinian people to escape their oppression is for them to achieve a semblance of political parity with Israel, which will only be achieved through international recognition.
An earlier report by the UN, the Palmer Report, declared the naval blockade on Gaza legal.

The Palmer Report was intended to mend relations between Turkey and Israel rather than provide a factual assessment of the situation. Not only was the report more political than factual in nature, it also relied exclusively on information provided by Turkey and Israel, hence its conclusions cannot be considered definitive in either fact or law.
Recognition of a Palestinian state is an important step in preventing Israeli de-facto annexation of Jewish settlements in the West Bank.
75% of Israelis would not support annexation without USA support, and it is unlikely to support annexation after recognizing Palestine as a state.
Israel has consistently ignored more UN Security Council decisions against it than any other country. It is unlikely to change its behaviour.

The US has not historically conducted its geopolitical strategies according to international law. As such, reducing the number of international law violations through recognition of Palestine is unlikely to be a significant motivator for change.
The US' continued use of drone strikes in undeclared war zones is illegal as per international law and may even constitute war crimes.
The US invasion of Iraq was illegal under international law.
Recognising Palestine could be viewed as a way for the US to divert attention away from more questionable parts of its foreign policy.
Just because the US does not base its geopolitical strategy on emphasising international law does not mean it should not do so.
It is morally important for the US to do the right thing even if it does not have the best moral track record.
International law and American support for it is actively denigrated if the US openly supports illegal policies for political gain.
The US supports governments who regularly breach human rights, including Egypt, Saudi Arabia, and the Philippines.
America has already taken a stance against settlements in the West Bank and, therefore, does not need to recognise Palestine as a state.
The US has been unable to stop Israel from expanding settlements. In fact, the rate of construction of such settlements has increased, so America does need to do more.

Trump has given mixed signals about the construction of settlements in the West Bank. Recognising Palestine as a state will be a firm indicator that America does not tolerate further expansion of settlements on Palestinian territory.
If recognition by many other nations is sufficient, there is no reason why the US should be pressured into recognizing Palestine as a state.
Recognising Palestine may jeopardise Israel's place in the region.
In the past, Jews have been killed and expelled from the territory now known as Palestine. Recognizing Palestine could legitimize the atrocities carried out previously and jeopardise Israel.
