Spoliation and massacres of Jews in Israel-Palestine can be traced to the 19th century Ottoman Empire and culminated to the complete Jordanian ethnic cleansing of half of Palestine.
Due to the prevention of any Jewish return to the region, Jewish people experienced gross atrocities with little capacity to escape.
In 1943, the leader of the Palestinian movement stated his support for the eradication of Jews.
In the Arab World, ethnic cleansing often happened to the Jewish Diaspora as Muslims stifled any right of return to Israel.
The Muslim rule at times didn't fully enforce the traditional Dhimmi status of Jews and sometimes, as in eleventh-century Granada, they were not considered second class citizens.
Relative equality for Jews in Granada ended in 1066 when Muslims massacred the Jewish community.
It is not clear how recognising self-determination for Palestinians would legitimise historical violence and anti-Semitism.
Israelis have a strong religious claim to Palestinian land; recognising Palestine would require giving up the land which is illegitimate.

Accounts of past Jewish sovereignty on the disputed territories are based on historical accounts not backed up by research and archaeological evidence.

The Egyptian Merneptah Stele confirms that Jews lived in Israel for more than 3000 years (the stele was created in 1208 BC).
The Moab stele (from a bronze-age state in modern day Jordan) confirms Jews lived in Israel 3000 years ago (840 BC).
It is unfair to base land ownership claims on artifacts because Palestinian artifacts have been seized or displaced by other countries, including Israel, in an effort to erase their identity.

Severe human rights violations occur under Israeli occupation.
Freedom of movement is often restricted for Palestinians.

These checkpoints are necessary to ensure the safety of civilians living in Israel, and are thus legal under Article 12 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.
There were nearly 500 attempts to smuggle weapons that checkpoints discovered.
Checkpoints and blockades are necessary because violent attackers blend into civilian crowds. For example, a bomb was found in an ambulance at the fifth checkpoint.
It is unjust to make innocent Palestinians suffer because of the threat a tiny proportion of them pose to Israel. This violates the proportionality principle and is therefore illegal.
Of the people who were killed by Israeli military forces or settlers in the West Bank during the past two years, all were civilians as defined by the UN.

In Hawara, the Israeli Defense Force blocked all but one road into the town leading to massive problems because of some 'stone-throwers'.

Israeli Defence Forces have deliberately attacked health workers, UNRWA Gaza shelters and hospitals. These attacks severely impair the ability of the Palestinian healthcare system to operate effectively.

In 2013, the Palestinian Authority cut its allocation for the Ministry of Health by 30 percent.
The Ministry of Health is currently in debt to pharmaceutical suppliers.

Projects by Israeli organizations help Palestinians to improve their medical training and business development.
The Peres Center has extended life-saving treatments to more than 12,000 Palestinian and Syrian children.
Charitable Israeli organizations can continue to improve Palestinian healthcare infrastructure, even in the absence of Israeli occupation.
Israeli occupation makes it difficult for Palestinians to fulfill their basic needs for food, water, and shelter.
Thousands of Palestinian homes and shops in East Jerusalem have been destroyed by the Israeli government.

About one-third of Gaza's arable land and 85 percent of its fishing waters are totally or partially inaccessible due to Israeli military measures. As a result, at least two-thirds of Gazan households lack secure access to food.
Many Palestinians suffer from malnutrition-related diseases due to a lack of access to food as a result of military barriers and movement restrictions.

An analysis comparing different possible solutions to the Israel-Palestine conflict predicted that withdrawal by Israel would pose significant threats to the socioeconomic welfare of Palestinians. This could further exacerbate the mental health crisis in Palestine.
The occupation allows Israel to stifle and control the economy of the West Bank and Gaza.
The professional and economic security of Palestinians is jeopardized because of Israeli occupation.
Israel's decision to withhold taxes from the Palestinian Authority causes a severe lack of funding for schools.
There are more universities now than before the West Bank occupation.

The Palestine Technical-Tulkarem University College and the Al-Ummah Community College were established before 1967 (p. 32).
Israel's control over Palestinian land use violates international regulations and deprives Palestinians of essential resources.

Palestinian quarries in the West Bank have been raided and requisitioned by Israeli military forces.
Palestinians' land is confiscated without compensation in order to allow construction.
Palestinian quarries are mainly supported by Israeli customers, propping up a vital industry that provides jobs and income for Palestinians.

Israel has currently established 14 economic zones in the West Bank that entrench its presence in the Palestinian territory.
Israeli blockades and draconian controls make it difficult for the Palestinian people to find gainful employment.

Israel-Palestine trade (pp. 3, 11) benefits the Palestinian economy significantly.
Palestinian purchases and sales from and to Israel account for two-thirds and 81% of total Palestinian imports and exports, respectively (p. 1).

The Israeli blockade of Gaza hampers UN relief work. Important construction material required for rebuilding houses and roads is not allowed to enter Gaza.
Gazans are, on average, worse off than in the 1990s.
The unemployment rate is significantly higher in Gaza (50%) - particularly among young Gazans - than in West Bank.

Since trade and investment are mutually beneficial, they would presumably continue even in the absence of occupation.

Israeli businesses within settlements provide tens of thousands of Palestinians with jobs and a source of income.

Israel's preferential treatment towards Israeli businesses forces Palestinians to depend on them, while Palestinian businesses are prevented from growing.

The security provided by Israeli forces in the West Bank allows for foreign investment to pour into the area.

Employed critics of the PA may face a series of punitive measures, including denial of promotion or transfer to distant areas, in response to their actions.

Leaders of other countries have established themselves as leaders for life, with no threats to the recognition of their states.

The boundaries marked by the 1949 Armistice Agreement signed by Israel and Egypt after the 1948 war were simply indicative of where the Egyptian and Israeli armies were. This left the territories up for negotiation.

The occupation was the result of Israel's "war of aggression and conquest" and not, as oftentimes argued, of a preventive and legitimate war for the purpose of self-defense.

Israel attempted to actively conceal laws that it had passed to effectively take over East Jerusalem; the Israeli Foreign Ministry told its ambassadors to refer to the annexation as "municipal fusion."

Israel refused to have UN peacekeeping forces stationed on its side of the border with Egypt to deescalate the conflict; Egypt had similar UN regiments stationed on its border from 1948 to 1967. Thus, Israel had the means to deescalate the conflict but actively decided against it.
Israel intended to return land to Jordan, in exchange for peace, as indicated by Resolution 242. This demonstrates that the objective of the Six-Day War was not territorial acquisition.
The government of Israel attempted by all means necessary to avoid any war with Jordan.
Levi Eshkol the Prime Minister at the time attempted, by all means, to avoid attacking Jordan.

Shortly after dealing with the Egyptian forces, the Israeli PM requested King Hussein not to enter the war through their shared UN contact to protect Jordan. However, a couple of hours later, Jordan began shelling civilian infrastructure in Jerusalem. Following extensive attacks from Jordan, Israel decided to retaliate.
Israel had issued a strict order that there was to be no shooting at the Jordanians. Israel did not want to open up a second front along its longest border.
In 1966, after a Palestinian land mine attack inside its territory, Israel conducted military reprisal operations on a large scale on Jordan-controlled territory.
UN Security Council Resolution 228 classified Israel's actions as a violation of the Armistice Agreement between Jordan and Israel.

The King of Jordan had previously told high-ranking Israeli government officials that he could not "absorb a serious retaliatory raid" by Israel. That Israeli raid, the Samu incident, is considered to be one of the aggravating factors that led to the Six-Day War.
The Samu incident was a legitimate reprisal operation against the Arabs planting mines in Jordan, which killed 3 Israeli soldiers.
Jordan, Egypt, and Syria refused to meet with Israel after the war, making peace impossible. This stopped negotiation during the Khartoum Resolution.

If Israel wanted to only attack Egypt and not capture any territory in Palestine, it could have given the captured territories back to Jordan after the war. By keeping these territories, Israel showed that capturing them was a desired end.
Israel has since made peace with Egypt and Jordan but has still not given back the territory of Palestine.
Many believe that Israel acted in self-defense in the Six-Day War.

Israel would not have had time to mobilise its reserve troops in case of a surprise attack, reducing its ability to defend itself against a first strike by the Arab nations.
There was a significant amount of Arab aggression in the region from Syria, Iraq, and Palestinian fedayeen, forcing Israel's hand prior to the Six-Day War.

The CIA assessed that Mossad's claim about being outgunned by the Arab nations was a deliberate attempt to influence the US into providing support for Israel and placing more pressure on the Egyptian President Nasser (p. 5).
The government of Israel believed that the Six Day War was one of self-defense.
The Israeli strike was considered, at the time and in the minutes of the Israeli government, as a preemptive strike within the context of a defensive war (pp. 220-221).
It was only after Jordan had blocked off Jerusalem's roads and cut off their access to water that Israel responded and captured the city.
Israel tried to keep Jordan out of the war with Egypt to avoid fighting a two-front war.
Fighting a two-front war would have split Israeli forces, weakening them.
Jordan was bound by a mutual defense treaty with Egypt and as such was obliged to act when Israel attacked Egypt. The war over the West Bank was, therefore, not a defensive one for Israel.

Intelligence collected by the CIA, and passed onto Israel, concluded that Israel's existence was not threatened by a potential attack from the Arab nations. In fact, President Johnson directly communicated this to the Israeli Foreign Minister, Abba Eban.
Both Israeli and US intelligence believed that the chances of Nasser striking first were slim.

Yitzhak Rabin, a General at the time of the Six-Day War and the future Prime Minister of Israel, believed that Nasser did not want war.
Egypt had closed the Straits of Tiran, blocking Israel's only supply route with Asia and stopping its main supply of oil from Iran, placing incredible pressure on Israel.

Nasser sent large numbers of troops to the Sinai Peninsula, threatened to destroy Israel, and called for preparations for the "final battle in Palestine." These acts clearly indicated that he was about to wage war with Israel.
The only nation to be pre-emptively struck was Egypt, which had moved their most threatening army to the Israeli border. Nations that controlled Palestine were not targeted.
While a defensive war to destroy enemy military capabilities might have been necessary, there was no need to continue occupying the land after the war.
Israeli occupation of Palestinian territories has been repeatedly acknowledged by international institutions, such as the UN, and the international community.

The UN Security Council's established unequivocal principle of acquisition makes inadmissable the acquisition of territory by war and leaves no room for dispute. Israel acquired Palestinian territories in 1967 by war and its claim to them is, therefore, illegitimate.
UN Security Council Resolution 2334 explicitly names Israel as "the occupying power" and refers to "Palestinian territories occupied since 1967, including East Jerusalem."

UN Security Council Resolution 242 following the Six-Day War demanded the "withdrawal of Israel armed forces from territories occupied in the recent conflict." This implies that the territories were considered as occupied.

In response to the deliberate attempt to obfuscate the language of the resolution, the Indian delegate to the UNSC remarked that an approved resolution would necessitate total withdrawal of Israeli forces from all the territories occupied by Israel since 5 June 1967. Several other UNSC members concurred emphatically.
If the resolution was content with partial Israeli withdrawal from the occupied territories, they would have likely used phrases such as "some" or "at least some" of the occupied territories.
The omission of the word "the" was intended to be vague; any claim to the contrary, that anything is explicitly specified, cannot be true.

Regarding the issue of partial withdrawal, a US State Department report concluded, "Support for the concept of total withdrawal was widespread in the Security Council, and it was only through intensive American efforts that a resolution was adopted which employed indefinite language in the withdrawal clause."
Despite several UNSC members proposing that "territories" be revised as "all-territories", the UN Security Council decided to use the former term.
The original authors of the UN Security Council Resolution 242 did not intend for the phrase to mean "all" (p. 4).

The guiding principle framing the text of the resolution in its preamble emphasizes "the inadmissibility of the acquisition of territory by war". This principle is unequivocal and incompatible with the claim that a partial withdrawal by Israel was considered acceptable.

Under UN Security Council Resolution 242, Israel is only expected to withdraw "from territories," not from "the territories" or "all the territories" captured during the Six-Day War, as noted by the then-British Foreign Secretary George Brown.

International law is not retroactive; thus, the events that occurred in 1967 cannot be interpreted in the light of laws instituted at a later time as is often done when Palestinian territories are designated as occupied (p. 377).
There are a variety of contexts in which acquisition through war is permissible, according to the UN charter.
Scholars have noted that, when engaging in a lawful war, acquisition is allowed.

The Declaration of Principles of International Law concerning Friendly Relations and Cooperation among States (UNGA resolutions 1970) includes the unqualified prohibition of the acquisition of territory by threat or use of force.
In a 2004 ruling, the Supreme Court of Israel noted that Israel had held the West Bank "in belligerent occupation" since 1967.
Disputed territories can still be under military occupation. As long as Israel uses the military to control an enemy's territory, Palestine can be considered occupied.
Recognizing Palestine while it is partially ruled by Hamas is equivalent to legitimizing a terrorist organization.
Recognizing Palestine whilst Hamas is control could send a problematic signal to other groups by showing that terrorism can garner US recognition more effectively than diplomatic action.
Leaders have previously claimed not to negotiate with terrorists to signal the strength of their ideological position, even if that is counter to reality.

The US classified the African National Congress as a terrorist organization until 2008.

America should not accept the establishment of a new state that would be de-facto controlled (if only in part) by a terrorist group.
Hamas, which governs part of the current Palestinian territory, does not recognize Israel as a state, let alone its Jewish statehood.

Hamas leaders have been outspoken about their objective of establishing a Palestinian state from the river to the sea as opposed to the Palestinian Authority's support for an agreement based on the 1967 lines.
Hamas could take over the West Bank and East Jerusalem, preventing access to Jews, as retaliation for recent Israeli restrictions on Palestinians visiting Al-Aqsa.

Whilst Hamas may have intended the chant in one manner, that is not how it is interpreted today by those who sing it.

When Israel withdrew from the Gaza Strip in 2005, it was taken over by Hamas, which then used the territory to launch numerous missile attacks on Israeli civilian targets. The same would happen in the case that Israel ends it presence in Palestinian territory.

From June 2004 to July 2014, 26 Israeli civilians (four of them minors) and two foreign nationals were killed in Israel as a result of rocket and mortar fire by Hamas. This will continue, and may increase, if Israel withdraws.

Hamas was forced to take over control of Gaza when President Mahmoud Abbas initially refused to surrender control of the government despite losing elections. This does not have to happen in the West Bank.
Iran has pledged to turn the West Bank into a launching pad for attacks on Israel, and arm Palestinians in the West Bank.

Hamas strategically attacks Israel when it runs out of money, in an attempt to force an agreement to relax its borders to allow finances to flow in. Recognition would mean lifting the blockade, eliminating the need for Hamas to attack Israel.
US recognition does not entail unilateral Israeli withdrawal from Palestinian territories.
It is possible to recognize Palestine as a state and simultaneously condemn Hamas as terrorists and illegitimate rulers of the area they control in Gaza.
India recognizes Palestine's statehood, but simultaneously condemns attacks carried out by Hamas.

China supports Palestine whilst maintaining economic links with Israel. This would likely be infeasible if the nation supported Hamas.

Reducing the potential for conflict between Israel and Palestine could weaken regional adversaries of the US and Israel.
Recognising Palestine might bring more co-operation between the PNSF and the IDF.

Palestinians often do not trust their security forces meaning that there is little capacity to reduce high tensions in the community.

Reducing the threat of Palestinian terror in the US, however minor, makes the world safer.

Palestinian liberation features prominently in Hamas propaganda used for radicalizing Palestinian youth.

Recognizing Palestine will jeopardize the security of Jewish settlers, as Palestine may wish to expel them and the protection offered by the IDF could be restricted.

Israel removed Israeli settlers from Gaza when it withdrew in 2005. It can simply do the same now.

Attempts to remove Israeli settlers from the small settlement of Amona resulted in violent clashes and pressure for a bill to legalize settlements.
Removal of Israeli settlers from Gaza led to violent clashes with the IDF and an emotive backlash from the settlers.
US recognition may lead to Israel recognising a Palestinian state and withdrawing from the occupied territories. This would heavily endanger Israeli security.

The occupied Golan Heights provide Israel with "important intelligence gathering capabilities" and are of vital strategic importance.

Israel fears that a military withdrawal from the West Bank could lead to an Islamist takeover of the area, similar to what happened in the Gaza Strip.
Israel's withdrawal from the Palestinian territories would help to reduce tensions in the region and thus contribute to Israel's security.
Palestinians refuse to recognise Israel as a Jewish state; it is, therefore, hypocritical of them to demand that other actors recognise them as a legitimate state.
Recognizing Israel would directly confer strategic benefits on Palestine while also indirectly dispelling any accusations of hypocrisy from the internal community.

By refusing to recognize Israel's right to exist, Palestine positions itself in opposition to many of its (potential) international supporters. This is likely to harm the Palestinian economy and society, as they are highly dependent on other nations.

Palestine opposing Israel's right to exist puts Germany in a problematic position vis-à-vis its support for Palestine. In the words of Angela Merkel, her country has a "special historical responsibility for Israel's security" which "will never be open to negotiation" (p. 6).
Opposing Israel's right to exist complicates relations with the US, whose presidents, such as Barack Obama, have extended their support to Israel.
The right to exist is a concept alien to international law, therefore Palestine cannot be punished through legal means.
Israel is a de jure state, and Palestine depends on Israel at the moment; it would, therefore, be counterintuitive for them to not recognize Israel.
Israel uses its claim as a Jewish state to block a peace deal with Palestinians.
Asking Palestinians to accept Israel's right to exist equals asking Palestinians to accept as justified what has been done to them over the course of the past decades.

Recognition by many other nations is a sufficient condition for a state to be legitimate. Therefore, Palestinian recognition of Israel has no positive effects on Israel, but strengthens Israel's position in relation to already occupied land, its general approach to the Palestinian people, and potential war crimes.
For many Palestinians, the existence of Israel is necessarily predicated on the 1948 expulsion of hundreds of thousands of Palestinians.
Palestinians would have had no reason to flee Israel, where they were a protected minority, had Israel not been simultaneously invaded by every one of its Arab neighbours in 1948.
Much of the harmful actions that the Israeli state has taken against Palestinians have been justified by citing general security concerns, not by citing its claims to the land.

If recognizing the Jewish state acknowledges or affirms Israeli atrocities or injustices committed against Palestinians, then recognizing the Palestinian state would affirm Palestinian atrocities and injustices committed against Israel.
Israel can be charged for state-sponsored crimes. However, this is not the case with Palestine, which is currently not recognized as a state.
No external authority has ever held Israel accountable for its state-sponsored crimes.
The Palestinian Authority has control only over a part of the land, and Israel already punishes those even suspected of violence and their families in Israel, in the West Bank, and Gaza.
Violence as a means of alleviating personally-perceived fear is not a legitimate argument.
Resistance to military occupation is a humanitarian right, not a crime.
This claim falsely assumes that resistance to military occupation is all that Palestians are guilty of in relation to atrocities committed against Israel.
In the war of 1948, Palestinian Arabs openly and proudly sought the total annihilation of the Jews.
The Geneva convention does not grant anybody the right to attack civilians or put civilians in danger through illegal actions. A war crime is a war crime.
Accepting Israel's right to exist as a Jewish state does not constitute accepting that all Israeli actions are acceptable.

Accepting Israel's right to exist as a Jewish state could be seen as a way to acknowledge the reality and legitimacy of Israel's existence and as desire for a future where both nations can exist in peace.
Israel uses its claim to the land of Palestine to normalise settlements on Palestinian territory and legitimise unjust actions. Acknowledging Israel as a Jewish state would entail accepting this.
Israel's Proclamation of Independence, issued May 14, 1948, invited the Palestinians to remain in their homes and become equal citizens in the new state.
One of the two former Prime Ministers of the Palestinian National Authority, Ismail Haniyeh, pledged that he will not recognise Israel.

The PLO's true aim is to subsume all of mandatory Palestine into a Palestinian state.

Other states have not recognised Israel as a Jewish state, or been asked to, yet the US does not refuse to recognise those states.
The Palestinian refusal to recognize Israel as a Jewish state is backed by the Arab League.

Jordan and Egypt are more powerful regional players than Palestine. Israel likely opted against demanding the pair to recognize Israel as a Jewish state in order to remain on good terms with them.
Several major American allies, such as Pakistan and Saudi Arabia, as well as states that receive large amounts of US support, such as Afghanistan and Iraq, do not recognize Israel either.
It would be difficult for the US to withdraw its recognition of established states. In contrast to that, it is easy to reject the recognition of a disputed state.

Iranian leaders have rejected Israel's right to exist on numerous occasions, going so far as to describe it as Iran's mission to erase Israel from the map.
All nations have rivals, and some may choose not to recognize another over a political spat; one country refusing to recognize Palestine does not justify others following suit.

Armenia and Azerbaijan do not recognize each other due to border conflicts; Morocco and Algeria have had political spats leading them to cut diplomatic ties with one another. Neither case is cause for the rest of the world to stop recognizing any of the countries involved.
Most other states are not proximate to Israel or heavily involved with Israel geopolitically, so whether they recognise Israel or not is mostly irrelevant. The same is not true for Palestine.
Accepting the Jewishness of Israel would mean giving up the 'right of return' for the Palestinian refugees who left during the 1948 exodus.

If this right to return is given up, up to 450,000 Palestinian refugees would be forced to continue to live in inhumane conditions in Lebanese refugee camps.

The "official" refugee community number is in the millions only because the surrounding Arab states refuse to grant citizenship to the millions of children and grandchildren born within their borders.

Even if a right to return for Palestinian refugees did exist, granting it would threaten Jewish culture within Israel and their national security because Palestinian refugees (7 million) outnumber the number of Jews in Israel (6.7 million).
Palestinian refugees do not have a clear right of return to Israel (p. 1).

Jewish leadership did not plan to expel Arabs from the state-to-be of Israel; rather, that was the consequence of outbreak of violence between Arabs and Jews. As a result, the state of Israel bears no responsibility for Palestinians refugees.
The refugee crisis was caused by the Arab invasion of Israel in 1948. Therefore, the respective Arab states are responsible for solving the crisis.

Many of the Palestinian Arabs who fled during the Arab invasion in 1948 did so voluntarily to avoid the ongoing war or at the urging of Arab leaders who promised that all who left would return after a quick Arab victory over the new Jewish state.

Some believe that the 1948 Palestinian exodus was the result of a planned ethnic cleansing implemented by Zionist leaders through systematic expulsions of villages and terrorist attacks against civilians (p. 15-16).
In 1978, the UN ruled that Palestinians have a right to return and enshrined this concept in Resolution 149.
The notion of a Palestinian 'right to return' is problematic.

Many ethnic Greeks and Turkish peoples could demand a right to return similar to the Palestinians. Yet, they do not.

Hundreds of thousands of Jews were expelled from Arab nations and many found a new home in Israel. These refugees have not been given a right of return to their homelands by Arab states, so it is hypocritical to demand that for Palestinian refugees.
Millions of Germans in Eastern Europe were expelled to Germany after World War II, but their explusion does not entitle them to a right of return.
The 'right to return' does not exist in contemporary international law as Palestinians would wish it to be recognised.
Being a victim of the injustice of expulsion does not necessarily grant the right to resettle in native lands.
The recognition of the Jewish character of a state and the recognition of the legitimacy of a state are not equivalent.
Recognizing a state as solely belonging to a religious or ethnic group is exclusionary and unnecessary.
The Palestinian Authority fears calling Israel a Jewish State will both increase and legitimise discrimination of Israel's Arab population.
Not recognizing Israel as a Jewish state is meant to protect the rights of the quarter of Israel's population that is not Jewish.

Israel is unique because it was founded as a Jewish state in response to thousands of years of global anti-Semitism that culminated in the Holocaust.

Anti-Semitism is widespread and increasing in Europe, US, UK, and Canada and around the world, all of which make having a safe haven for Jews necessary.
The demand for recognition as a Jewish state is new and surfaced only recently at the Annapolis Conference of 2007.
The demand to recognize Israel as a Jewish state is a delaying tactic used by Israel.

Most countries delay their recognition of other fledgling states in order to balance their arguments and come up with a decision.

Israel's Declaration of Independence states that Israel is a Jewish state, making it clear that this is a key aspect of the state's foundational identity.
Historically, external actors have recognised the need for a Jewish state. This later became Israel.
Iran is generally referred to as the "Islamic Republic of Iran", even in the list of UN member states.
It is possible to be a Jewish state and still protect non-Jewish minorities.
Israeli law, including the Declaration of Independence, highlights that the state will "ensure complete equality [...] to all its inhabitants irrespective of religion".
The Supreme Court of Israel in CA 6698/95 made it clear that discrimination against non-Jews is illegal (p. 27).

Israel is a Jewish state in that it is designed to be a safe homeland for Jews throughout the world, not in that it is a state exclusively for Jews.
Palestinians are asking only for recognition of Palestine as a state, not as a Muslim state. Therefore, their refusal to recognise Israel as a Jewish state is not hypocritical.

Jews are forbidden from praying at the Temple Mount, even though it is located in Jerusalem.
Recognition of a Jewish state doesn't necessarily imply that religious sites within Israel are primarily Jewish.
The US should not support the two-state solution, as it is not the best outcome for the region.
A one-state solution encompassing both Israel and Palestine would allow both groups to inhabit the same space in peace.
Palestinians have a strong claim to the territory. Israel, therefore, shouldn't be given an exclusive right to the territory.
The vast majority of Palestinians, by virtue of being Muslims, have a strong religious connection to the territory.

According to the Torah, Abraham had two sons: Ishmael and Isaac. Ishmael and Isaac are considered respectively the ancestors of the Arab people and the Jewish people. Muslims have holy sites that are located both in and outside Israel, but all Jewish holy sites are located in Israel.

Palestinians want, first and foremost, a state of their own as Palestinian Arab people. In 1988 their parliament thus adopted a declaration of independence. Ever since, November 15 is celebrated as Independence Day in Palestine.
Palestinian textbooks display a world without Israel and incite antisemitic feelings. This mindset precludes solution.

The citizenship of Palestinians in a joint state with Israelis that ensures equal rights for everybody could deliver this independence.

Before the program of expulsion from Arab countries, including Palestine, Jewish people had been living in the territory as well.

Several binding instruments of international law grant sovereign rights to the Jewish people in the land of Israel. Zero binding instruments of international law support the claims of the Palestinian Arabs.
Reports on polls indicate that more Israelis (39%) support a joint state for the two peoples than support a two-state solution (30%).
The former Israeli President, Reuven Rivlin, has said that he would rather accept Palestinians as Israeli citizens than accept the creation of a Palestinian state.

The popular Palestinian political slogan, "From the river to the sea, Palestine will soon be free," suggests that the end goal is total Palestinian control, which some believe borders on genocidal intent.

24% of Arab citizens believe that Israel is in good or very good condition, compared to 42% of Jews (p. 1). This indicates that Arab citizens are not satisfied with their situation in the state.
Arab towns and villages are heavily over-represented in the lowest socio-economic rankings of Israel, and the unrecognized Arab Bedouin villages in the Naqab are the poorest communities in the state.
Citizenship rights for Jewish and Arab citizens are not equal (p. 16). This extends to laws around immigration and family unification.

The expulsions in Sheikh Jarrah in the summer of 2021 have highlighted the ways in which Israeli real estate legislation directly discriminates against those who would consider themselves Palestinian.
In 2010, only 51% of the Jewish citizens of Israel supported equal rights between the Jewish and Arab citizens of the country.
Eight out of ten Israeli Arabs believe that there is already "a lot" of discrimination against Arabs taking place in Israel.

The cited survey indicates that 72% of ultra-orthodox Jews believe this, whilst only 33.5% of secular Jews do. This is important as the ultra-orthodox are likely to be a major voting block in Israel's future.
86% believe that critical decisions for the state should be taken only by a Jewish majority.
The 2021 elections featured an Arab party in the winning coalition. This indicates that this attitude might be changing.
As of 2021, Israeli voters have become more supportive of Ra'am involvement in the governance of the Knesset. This indicates a positive change in attitude towards Arabs.
Inequalities between Arab and Jewish citizens of Israel are universal and enduring (p. 7).
In 2021, the Supreme Court of Israel voted to uphold a 2018 law that downgrades the status of non-Jewish Israeli citizens.
About half of all Israeli Jews voice in opinion polls that Arabs should be transferred or even expelled from Israel.
Right wing foreign minister Avigdor Lieberman already plans to swap Arab-Israeli villages in Israel with Jewish-Israeli settlements in the West Bank.
Even if Israel has no intent of treating Palestinians as equals, increased global scrutiny on the state may pressure them into taking more positive actions.
As no workable alternative is in sight, the only viable option for Israel and Palestine is the continuation and mutual acceptance of the political status quo.
Palestinians have been consistently responsible for the failure of peace processes, forcing Israel to maintain an occupying force in order to protect itself.
Israel has offered Palestine sovereignty on multiple occasions, these offers have been consistently rejected.
US officials blame Abbas for 'shutting down' during the 2014 peace negotiations, even though Israel was prepared for an agreement.

Abbas had no choice but to walk away from those negotiations as Israel refused to stop expanding its settlements, a move designed to undermine Abbas and portray him as having made a peace deal by selling off Palestinian land.

A US-European draft resolution at the UN Security Council that would have extended the Palestinian Authority's authority to the Gaza Strip and stipulated the immediate start of reconstruction was rejected by the Palestinian Authority itself.

After disillusionment with Israel's refusal to negotiate and arrive at a peace treaty, Mahmoud Abbas, the president of the Palestinian Authority, sought to bypass the peace process with Israel, showing that he believed it to be beyond recovery.
Abbas rejected a peace proposal made by Olmert in 2008.
Olmert blames the failure of the peace process on Israeli ministers Tzipi Livni and Ehud Barak.
Olmert's offer lacked transparency as he was unwilling to provide a map of the envisioned partition of Jerusalem. Therefore, the offer was difficult to accept.
Almost two thirds of Palestinians support abandoning the Oslo Accords, and thereby the foundations of the American-supported peace talks.
Abbas has consistently, and recently, accepted the two-state solution. Rejection of individual peace plans because of their flaws is not the same as rejecting the two-state solution itself.
Israel has also rejected peace plans, yet that does not mean it has rejected the two-state solution.
Netanyahu rejected a peace plan proposed by former US Secretary of State John Kerry in a secret 2016 meeting.
Israel rejected an Arab peace initiative in 2007.
Palestinian militants are a threat to Israel.

When Israel withdrew from the Gaza Strip in 2005, it was taken over by Hamas, which then used the territory to launch numerous missile attacks on Israeli civilian targets. The same would happen in the case that Israel ends its presence in Palestinian territory.

If Israel does not militarily control the West Bank then it would have to take military actions to curb missile attacks, as was carried out in Gaza in 2008, and 2012. This results in excessive civilian casualties, and the destruction of infrastructure.
Israel already easily defends itself from these missile attacks from Gaza using the Iron Dome missile defense system. The success of this system makes obsolete the need for continued occupation.
Iron Dome can intercept approximately 90% of all projectiles fired from Gaza.
Each interceptor missile costs $20,000-$50,000 USD. Continually utilizing missile defense would drain the Israeli security budget.
Iron Dome is still not a perfect defense. In the 2014 Gaza War, Israeli civilians were still killed by rocket fire from Gaza.
The number of Israelis killed by Palestinian militants is so small - less than 100 Israelis per year - that it could not be considered a legitimate security concern.
Palestinians list preconditions to engage in peace talks. If a party needs to be brought back to the negotiation table, it is Palestine.

The Oslo Accords were a land-for-peace deal. Israeli settlement expansions and the creation of a security barrier that encroached on Palestinian land were clear indications of Israel's non-compliance with the peace agreement.
If the occupation had reasons to believe in a serious threat, Israeli civilians would not be allowed to settle there.
Settlers often say they live in occupied Palestine because the land was promised to them by God.
The failure of the Camp David negotiations in 2000 were the result of Israel's unacceptable demands.
Israel demanded a demilitarized state (p. 16). This would have abrogated Palestine's right to self-determination.

In an interview, Barak admitted that a "razor-thin" strip of territory between Jerusalem and the Jordan River would have been transferred to Israeli control. This would have cut the West Bank apart and therefore was not acceptable to the Palestinians.
Barak's offer was not sufficient as it only envisioned a gradual control over only 92% of the West Bank (p. 16).

As of 2009, a majority of Palestinians were willing to accept or even embrace a continuation of the political status quo under the condition that the Palestinian territories would be able to develop economically (p. 4).

"Israeli-imposed economic restrictions continue to constrain sustainable economic growth" in Palestine. By removing these restrictions, it would be possible to promote economic growth without large-scale political change.

Economic mobility within the West Bank is hindered substantially by a system of blockades and checkpoints. Given that these are maintained for security reasons to prevent terrorist attacks, Israel will never agree to lift them.
The attitude of Palestinians has probably changed dramatically since 2009, especially considering major events since then like the 2014 war in Gaza.
As of 2009, three-quarters of Israelis found the continuation of the status quo at least tolerable and more than half found it to be acceptable or even desirable (p. 4).

The intractability of the conflict (pp. 610-619) between Palestinians and Israel (p. 71) has been linked to underlying emotions and collective emotional (pp. 447-450) orientations that fuel thinking and beliefs which make any progress next to impossible, especially as strong emotions are often immune to logical argumentation.
Israelis benefit the most by maintaining the status quo; their attitudes should not be considered especially important when evaluating if things should change.
Israel currently controls most of the water supply within the West Bank.
